sentence:
[Witness graphs]
 A witness graph of depth j for x is a rooted subgraph W_j=W_j(x) of G_n,k satisfying the following:


  (I) The vertex set of W_j is V=‚à™_i=0^j V_i, where


  * V_i‚äÇ B_i for all i

  * V_j={x}


  (II) For i‚â• 1, each vertex in V_i has at least one neighbor in V_i-1 and exactly r neighbors in V_0‚à™‚ãØ‚à™ V_i-1.

If there are two adjacent vertices u and v in W_j, where u‚àà V_s and v‚àà V_t with s<t, then we say that v is a parent of u and we also say that u is a child of v. 
Hence, except the vertices in V_0, every vertex has r children, and except the root vertex, every vertex has at least one parent (there may be many). Finally,  although it is just a technicality, we view W_j as a directed graph, where the edges are oriented toward the children. (See Figure¬†<ref>.)

A rooted ribbon tree (RRT) is a tree T with a choice of a root Œ±_‚àà T and a cyclic ordering of the edges incident to each vertex; we orient such a tree toward the root.
We say that a vertex Œ± of an RRT T is interior if the set (Œ±) of its incoming neighbors is nonempty, and we denote the set of interior vertices of T by T_.
An RRT T is stable if every interior vertex has at least 2 incoming edges.
We define K^_r to be the set of all isomorphism classes of stable rooted ribbon trees with r leaves.

We denote the i-th leaf of an RRT T by Œª_i^T.
For any Œ±, Œ≤‚àà T, T_Œ±Œ≤ denotes those vertices Œ≥ such that the path [Œ±,Œ≥] from Œ± to Œ≥ passes through Œ≤.
We denote T_Œ± T_Œ±_Œ±.

sentence:
A Schr√∂der tree is either a leaf, or consists of a root vertex 
with an ordered k-tuple of subtrees attached to the root (k ‚â• 2),
which are themselves Schr√∂der trees. 

Non-leaf vertices of a tree are called internal vertices . 

We consider only finite Schr√∂der trees, i.e. , those having finitely many leaves and internal vertices. 

In our context, the size of a tree t is its number of leaves. 
It is denoted |t|, 
whereas #t denotes the number of vertices of t (including both leaves and internal vertices).

sentence:
[Contour C_t]
Let t be a (binary or Schr√∂der) tree. Recall that #t denotes the total number of vertices of t, and denote by V the set of vertices of t. 

Consider the function _t: {0,1, ‚Ä¶, 2 #t-2}‚Üí V ( stands for depth first search) defined by: 

 
  * _t(0) is the root of t; 
 
  * if _t(i) =v, then _t(i+1) 
 is the leftmost child of v that has not yet been visited, if it exists,
 and the parent of v otherwise. 

The contour of t is the function C_t:[0,2 #t-2] ‚Üí [0;+‚àû) such that 
for all integers i in [0,2 #t-2], C_t(i) is the distance from the root of t to the vertex _t(i), 
and C_t is linear between those points.

    for all  u ‚àà [0,1],   C_t(u)=1/‚àö(|t|) C_t( (2#t-2)  u ).

sentence:

sentence:
Let G=(  V,E) be a graph.

(a) We define a binary relation ‚àº_G (written infix) on the set
V as follows: Given u‚àà V and v‚àà V, we set u‚àº_Gv if and only
if u and v are connected (in G). It is well-known that this relation
‚àº_G is an equivalence relation. The ‚àº_G-equivalence classes are
called the connected components of G.

(b) Assume that the graph G is finite. We let Œª(
G) denote the list of the sizes of all connected components of G,
in weakly decreasing order. (Each connected component should contribute only
one entry to the list.) We view Œª(  G) as a partition
(since Œª(  G) is a weakly decreasing finite list of
positive integers).

sentence:
Let G=(  V,E) be a graph. A cycle of
G denotes a list (  v_1,v_2,‚Ä¶,v_m+1) of elements
of V with the following properties:



  * We have m>1.


  * We have v_m+1=v_1.


  * The vertices v_1,v_2,‚Ä¶,v_m are pairwise distinct.


  * We have {  v_i,v_i+1}‚àà E for every i‚àà{
1,2,‚Ä¶,m}.


If (  v_1,v_2,‚Ä¶,v_m+1) is a cycle of G, then the
set {{  v_1,v_2}  ,{  v_2,v_3}
,‚Ä¶,{  v_m,v_m+1}} is called a
circuit of G.

sentence:
Let G=(  V,E) be a graph. Let X be a totally
ordered set. Let ‚Ñì:E‚Üí X be a function. We shall refer to ‚Ñì
as the labeling function . For every edge e of G, we shall refer

A broken circuit of G means a subset of E having the form
C‚àñ{  e}, where C is a circuit of G, and where e
is the unique edge in C having maximum label (among the edges in C). Of
course, the notion of a broken circuit of G depends on the function ‚Ñì;
however, we suppress the mention of ‚Ñì in our notation, since we will not
consider situations where two different ‚Ñì's coexist.

sentence:
Let G=(  V,E) be a finite graph. Theorem
<ref> shows that there exists a polynomial P‚àà‚Ñ§[  x] such that every q‚àà‚Ñï satisfies
P(  q)  =(  the number of all proper {
1,2,‚Ä¶,q}-colorings of G). This polynomial P is

sentence:
(a) A digraph means a pair (
V,A), where V is a set, and where A is a subset of V^2.
Digraphs are also called directed graphs . A digraph (
V,A) is said to be finite if the set V is finite. If
D=(  V,A) is a digraph, then the elements of V are called the
vertices of the digraph D, while the elements of A are called the
arcs (or the directed edges ) of the digraph D. If
a=(  v,w) is an arc of a digraph D, then v is called the
source of a, whereas w is called the target of a.

(b) A digraph (  V,A) is said to be loopless
if every v‚àà V satisfies (  v,v)  ‚àâ A. (In other words, a
digraph is loopless if and only if it has no arc whose source and target are identical.)

(c) A digraph (  V,A) is said to be
transitive if it has the following property: For any u‚àà V, v‚àà
V and w‚àà V satisfying (  u,v)  ‚àà A and (
v,w)  ‚àà A, we have (  u,w)  ‚àà A.

(d) A digraph (  V,A) is said to be 2
-path-free if there exist no three elements u, v and w of V
satisfying (  u,v)  ‚àà A and (  v,w)  ‚àà A.

(e) Let D=(  V,A) be a loopless digraph. Define a map
*set:A‚ÜíV2 by setting

    (  *set(  v,w)  ={  v,w}          for every (  v,w)  ‚àà A)  .

(It is easy to see that *set is well-defined, because
(  V,A) is loopless.) The graph (  V,*set
A) will be denoted by D.

sentence:
Let M=(  E,‚Ñê) be a matroid.

(a) We define a function r_M:ùí´(  E)
‚Üí‚Ñï by setting

    r_M(  S)  =max{| Z| | Z‚àà‚Ñê and Z‚äÜ S}          for every S‚äÜ E.

(Note that the right hand side of (<ref>) is well-defined,
because there exists at least one Z‚àà‚Ñê satisfying Z‚äÜ S
(namely, Z=‚àÖ).) If S is a subset of E, then the nonnegative
integer r_M(  S) is called the rank of S (with
respect to M). It is clear that r_M is a weakly increasing function from
the poset ùí´(  E) to ‚Ñï.

(b) If k‚àà‚Ñï, then a k-flat of M means a
subset of E which has rank k and is maximal among all such subsets (i.e.,
it is not a proper subset of any other subset having rank k). (Beware: Not
all k-flats have the same size.) A flat of M is a subset of E
which is a k-flat for some k‚àà‚Ñï. We let *FlatsM
denote the set of all flats of M; thus, *FlatsM is a
subposet of ùí´(  E).

(c) A circuit of M means a minimal element of
ùí´(  E)  ‚àñ‚Ñê. (That is, a circuit of
M means a subset of E which is not independent (for M) and which is
minimal among such subsets.)

(d) An element e of E is said to be a loop (of M) if
{  e}‚àâ‚Ñê. The matroid M is said to be
loopless if no loops (of M) exist.

sentence:
Let P be a poset.

(a) An element p‚àà P is said to be a global minimum of
P if every q‚àà P satisfies p‚â§ q. Clearly, a global minimum of P is
unique if it exists.

(b) An element p‚àà P is said to be a global maximum of
P if every q‚àà P satisfies p‚â• q. Clearly, a global maximum of P is
unique if it exists.

(c) Let x and y be two elements of P. An upper bound
of x and y (in P) means an element z‚àà P satisfying z‚â• x and
z‚â• y. A join (or least upper bound ) of x and y (in
P) means an upper bound z of x and y such that every upper bound
z^' of x and y satisfies z^'‚â• z. In other words, a
join of x and y is a global minimum of the subposet {  w‚àà
P | w‚â• x and w‚â• y} of P. Thus, a join of x and
y is unique if it exists.

(d) Let x and y be two elements of P. A lower bound of
x and y (in P) means an element z‚àà P satisfying z‚â§ x and z‚â§
y. A meet (or greatest lower bound ) of x and y (in P)
means a lower bound z of x and y such that every lower bound z^' of x and y satisfies z^'‚â§ z. In other words, a meet of x
and y is a global maximum of the subposet {  w‚àà P | w‚â§
x and w‚â§ y} of P. Thus, a meet of x and y is unique
if it exists.

(e) The poset P is said to be a lattice if and only if it
has a global minimum and a global maximum, and every two elements of P have
a meet and a join.

sentence:
Let P be a poset.

(a) If x and y are two elements of P satisfying x‚â§ y, then
the set {  z‚àà P | x‚â§ z‚â§ y} is denoted by
[  x,y].

(b) A subset of P is called a closed interval of P if it
has the form [  x,y] for two elements x and y of P

(c) We denote by *IntP the set of all closed
intervals of P.

(d) If f:*IntP‚Üí‚Ñ§ is any map, then
the image f(  [  x,y]  ) of a closed interval
[  x,y]  ‚àà*IntP under f will be abbreviated by
f(  x,y).

(e) Assume that every closed interval of P is finite. The
M√∂bius function of the poset P is defined to be the unique
function Œº:*IntP‚Üí‚Ñ§ having the following
two properties:



  * We have

    Œº(  x,x)  =1          for every x‚àà P.




  * We have

    Œº(  x,y)  =-‚àë_z‚àà P;
    x‚â§ z<yŒº(
    x,z)            for all x,y‚àà P satisfying x<y.




(It is easy to see that these two properties indeed determine Œº uniquely.)
This M√∂bius function is denoted by Œº.

sentence:
Left insertion , middle insertion and right insertion , denoted¬†L(œï),¬†M(œï) and¬†R(œï), respectively, are operators on Bruhat logic gates defined as follows. The terms left, middle and right are all oriented with respect to the penultimate block. Left insertion inserts the element¬†1 into¬†œï immediately to the left of the penultimate block, and shifts all other elements up by¬†1. Middle insertion increases the length of the penultimate block by¬†1. sentence:
A cluster algebra has polynomial growth if the number of
distinct seeds which can be obtained from a fixed initial seed by at most n mutations is bounded from above by
a polynomial function of¬†n.  A cluster algebra has exponential growth
if the number of such seeds is bounded from below by an exponentially
growing function of¬†n.

  * Dividing independence: ad_C b if and only if for any C-indiscernible (b_i)_i‚ààœâ in (b/C), there is a' such that a'b_i‚â°_C ab for all i‚ààœâ.

  * Forking independence: af_C b if and only if for any tuple b, there is a'‚â°_Cba such that ad_C bb. 

  * Kim dividing independence: If C is a model, then aKd_C b if and only if for any Morley sequence (b_i)_i‚ààœâ in a global C-invariant type extending (b/C), there is a' such that a'b_i‚â°_C ab for all i‚ààœâ.

  * Kim forking independence: If C is a model, then aK_C b if and only if for any tuple b, there is a'‚â°_Cba such that aKd_C bb. 

Recall  that, for any C‚äÇ and a,b‚àà, we have af_C b‚áí ad_C b‚áí aa_C b, and if C is a model, we have ad_C b‚áí aKd_C b‚áí aa_C b.

sentence:
Let  be a ternary relation on (small subsets of) T. We say  is invariant if it is invariant under automorphisms of . Consider the following axioms.


  * Monotonicity: If A_C B, A' A, and B' B, then A'_C B'.

  * Base monotonicity: If A_C B and C D(BC) then A_D B.

  * Symmetry: If A_C B then B_C A.

  * Transitivity: If D C B, A_D C, and A_C B then A_D B.

  * Finite character: If A_C B then A_C B_0 for some finite B_0 B. 

  * Local character: For all A there is some cardinal Œ∫ such that for all B, there is C B with |C|‚â§Œ∫ and A_C B. 

  * Existence: A_C C for all A and C.

  * Full existence: For all A,B,C there is A'‚â°_C A such that A'_C B.

  * Extension: If A_C B and B‚äá BC, then there is A'‚â°_BC A such that A'_C B.

  * Stationarity: For all A,A',B,C, if A'‚â°_C A, A_C B, and A'_C B, then A'‚â°_BC A.

  * The independence theorem: If M T and A_M B, A'_M C, B_M C, and A‚â°_M A', then there is A‚Äù such that A‚Äù‚â°_MB A, A‚Äù‚â°_MCA', and A‚Äù_M BC.

  * Strong finite character and witnessing: If M T and A_M B, then there are a‚àà A, b‚àà B, and œÜ(x,b)‚àà(a/BM), such that if a'œÜ(x,b) then a'_M b, and if (b_i)_i‚ààœâ is a Morley sequence in a global invariant type extending (b/M), then {œÜ(x,b_i) | i‚ààœâ} is inconsistent.

If an element m‚àà P is a maximal element that only covers minimal elements or a minimal element that is only covered by maximal elements, call m extremal-atomic .

sentence:
Given a poset P and an ordered subset of elements {p_1,p_2,‚Ä¶, p_n} in  P, 
define P_i recursively as the induced subposet P_i:=P_i-1‚àñ p_i with P_0:=P.
If P_n is a chain with at least three elements,  p_i+1 is maximal or minimal in P_i for each 0‚â§ i‚â§ n-1, and each P_i has connected Hasse diagram and no extremal-atomic element, call P strongly-extremal-atomic-free .

sentence: A cut of a graph is a partition of the vertices into two disjoint subsets. A cut determines a cut-set , defined as the set of edges that have one endpoint in each subset of the partition.

sentence:
A finite matroid M may be defined as a pair (E,‚Ñê), where E is a finite set (called the ground set) and ‚Ñê is a set of subsets of E (called the independent sets) with the following properties:



  * ‚àÖ‚àà‚Ñê;

  * For each X‚äÜ Y‚äÜ E, if Y‚àà‚Ñê then X‚àà‚Ñê (the hereditary property); and

  * If X,Y‚àà‚Ñê and |Y|>|X|, then there exists y‚àà Y‚àñ X such that X‚à™{y}‚àà‚Ñê (the independent set exchange property).


A maximal independent subset is a basis . A subset of E is dependent if it is not independent (that is, not in ‚Ñê). A minimal dependent subset of E is a circuit .

sentence:
The representation with a minimum total number of terms
among all possible representations of Ex(FG) derived by the decomposition
method is achieved if and only if in each recursive step i is equal to q+p/2 for odd q-p+1 and to q+p-1/2 or q+p+1/2
for even q-p+1, i.e., when i is a middle vertex of the interval (p,q).
Such a decomposition method is called optimal .

Let B(S,œÅ) be a Bohr set.  The regular probability distribution ùî≠_B(S,œÅ): /p‚Üí associated to B(S,œÅ) is the function defined by the formula

    ùî≠_B(S,œÅ)(a)   2 ‚à´_1/2^1 1_B(S,tœÅ)(a)/|B(S,tœÅ)| dt;

it is easy to see from Fubini's theorem that this is indeed a probability distribution on /p.  A random variable ‚àà/p is said to be drawn regularly from B(S,œÅ) if it has probability density function ùî≠_B(S,œÅ), thus (  = a ) = ùî≠_B(S,œÅ)(a) for all a ‚àà/p.

More generally, for any shifted Bohr set n + B(S,œÅ), we define the regular probability distribution ùî≠_n+B(S,œÅ): /p‚Üí by the formula

    ùî≠_n+B(S,œÅ)(a) ùî≠_B(S,œÅ)(a-n),

Let B be a subset of /p, and let G = (G,+) be an abelian group.  A function œï: B ‚Üí G is said to be locally linear on B if one has

    œï(n+h_1+h_2) - œï(n+h_1) - œï(n+h_2) + œï(n) = 0

whenever n,h_1,h_2 ‚àà/p are such that n,n+h_1,n+h_2,n+h_1+h_2 ‚àà B.  Similarly, œï is said to be locally quadratic on B if one has

    ‚àë_(œâ_1,œâ_2,œâ_3) ‚àà{0,1}^3 (-1)^œâ_1+œâ_2+œâ_3œï(n+œâ_1 h_1+œâ_2 h_2 + œâ_3 h_3) = 0

whenever n,h_1,h_2,h_3 ‚àà/p are such that n + œâ_1 h_1 + œâ_2 h_2 + œâ_3 h_3 ‚àà B for all (œâ_1,œâ_2,œâ_3) ‚àà{0,1}^3.

A function œà: B √ó B ‚Üí G is said to be locally bilinear on B if one has

    œà(h_1+h'_1, h_2) = œà(h_1,h_2) + œà(h'_1,h_2)

whenever h_1,h'_1,h_2 ‚àà B are such that h_1+h'_1 ‚àà B, and similarly one has

    œà(h_1,h_2+h'_2) = œà(h_1,h_2) + œà(h_1,h'_2)

whenever h_1,h_2,h'_2 ‚àà B are such that h_2+h'_2 ‚àà B.

sentence:
<cit.>
    A graph-like space¬†G is a topological space (also denoted by¬†G) 
    together with a vertex set¬†V(G), 
    an edge set¬†E(G) 
    and for each¬†e ‚àà E(G) a continuous map¬†Œπ_e^G:[0,1]‚Üí G 
    (the superscript may be omitted if¬†G is clear from the context) such that:
    
        
  * The underlying set of¬†G is¬†V(G) ‚à™Ãá [(0,1)√ó E(G)].
        
  * For any¬†x ‚àà (0,1) and¬†e ‚àà E(G) we have¬†Œπ_e(x)=(x,e).
        
  * Œπ_e(0) and¬†Œπ_e(1) are vertices (called the end-vertices of¬†e).
        
  * Œπ_e‚Üæ_(0,1) is an open map.
        
  * For any two distinct¬†v, v' ‚àà V(G), there are disjoint open subsets¬†U, U' of¬†G partitioning¬†V(G) and with¬†v ‚àà U and¬†v' ‚àà U'.
    
    The inner points of the edge¬†e are the elements of¬†(0,1) √ó{ e }.

The potential of a sequence of positive integers d_1,d_2,‚Ä¶,d_n is defined by

[van der Waerden]

van der Waerden's theorem
Consider the set of natural numbers  and imagine that we paint each number with one of r different colors. In other words, consider a partition

    =  C

where C_i is the subset of natural numbers painted with the i-th color. Then, for any given length k, there exists at least one arithmetic progression

[Partition regularity]
Let ùí¢ be a nonempty collection of sets that we deem interesting, for instance

    ùí¢ = {{a,a+b,‚Ä¶,a+(k-1)b} : a,b‚àà, b > 0}

[Notions of ideals]
ideal!left, right, two-sided
ideal!minimal left ideal
ideal!minimal two-sided ideal@minimal two-sided ideal 
Consider a left topological semigroup (S,+), for example the space of ultrafilters S=. A subset I‚äÜ S is called


  * a left ideal if p+I ‚äÜ I for every element p‚àà S.

  * a right ideal if I+p ‚äÜ I for every element p‚àà S.

  * a minimal left ideal if it is a left ideal and does not contain a proper subset that is also a left ideal.

  * an ideal , or two-sided ideal , if it is both a left and a right ideal.

  * a minimal ideal if it is a two-sided ideal and does not contain a proper subset that is also a two-sided ideal.

Suppose that M is a mutation class of diagrams with 3 vertices. Let Œì_0 be the diagram in M such that s(Œì_0) is minimal as in the Theorem¬†<ref>. Then we have the following:









  (i)
Œì_0 is the unique, upto the same conditions as in Theorem¬†<ref>, diagram in M such that, for each vertex i, we have s(Œì_0)‚â§ s(Œº_i(Œì_0)).


  (ii)
For each Œì in M, there is a (possibly empty) sequence {Œº_i} of mutations with Œì_0=Œº_1...Œº_n(Œì) such that for Œì_i-1=Œº_i...Œº_n(Œì) we have s(Œì_i-1)<s(Œì_i), here i=1,...,n with Œì_n=Œì. Furthermore, if Œì is mutation-cyclic then the sequence {Œº_i} is uniquely determined: specifically, the vertex i is the vertex which is not incident to the edge with maximal [We will show that Œì_i+1 has a unique edge with maximal weight (Lemma¬†<ref>). ] weight in Œì_i+1, i=0,1,...,n-1.  



Conversely, for any maximal sequence {Œº_i:i=1,...,n} such that s(Œì_i-1)<s(Œì_i) with Œì_i-1=Œº_i...Œº_n(Œì) and Œì_n=Œì, we have Œì_0=Œº_1...Œº_n(Œì).

sentence:
Two edges e,f‚àà E(G) are in the relation Œ¥ , e f, 
if one of the following conditions is satisfied:


  (i)   e and f are opposite edges of a chordless square.

  (ii)  e and f are adjacent and there is no chordless square 
             containing e and f. 

  (iii) e=f.

sentence:
An equivalence relation R on E(G) has the 
  unique square property if it satisfies
  
  
  (S1) Any two adjacent edges e and f from distinct equivalence
  classes span a unique chordless square with opposite edges in the same
  equivalence class R.
  
  R has the square property if it satisfies in addition 
  
  
  (S2) The opposite edges of any chordless square belong to the 
    same equivalence class.

sentence:
An equivalence relation R on the edge set of a connected graph G 
  is called a USP-relation if there exists a finer equivalence 
  relation Q‚äÜ R that satisfies the unique square property.

sentence:
Suppose F has nonempty subgraphs F_1 and F_2 such
that V(F)=V(F_1)‚à™ V(F_2), V(F_1)‚à© V(F_2)=‚àÖ and
precisely four edges of F connect F_1 to F_2. Group these four edges
into two pairs, and reassemble the four half-edges from each pair into two new
edges, each of which connects F_1 to F_2. The resulting graph
F^' is obtained from F by balanced mutation .

of cyclic permutations x_1...x_2n‚Ü¶ x_i...x_2nx_1...x_i-1

sentence:
A disjoint family of double occurrence words is a finite set {W_1,
..., W_k} of double occurrence words, no two of which share any letter.
The interlacement graph of {W_1,...,W_k} is the union of the
interlacement graphs of W_1,...,W_k.

sentence:
An equivalence between two disjoint families of
double occurrence words is some sequence of the following operations:
cyclically permuting a word, reversing a word, replacing two disjoint words
with their concatenation, and separating a concatenation of two disjoint words
into the two separate words.

sentence:
A turnaround of a disjoint family of double
occurrence words is a disjoint family obtained by applying a turnaround to
some element of the original disjoint family.

sentence:
(Main Theorem)
Suppose we are given fractional hitting sets Q_1, ‚Ä¶, Q_K for ‚Ñ¨_1, ‚Ä¶, ‚Ñ¨_K respectively.

In each of the following three cases, 
the PRA terminates in a feasible configuration avoiding all bad events with probability one. 

(a) Suppose there exists Œº: 2^ùí≥√ó [K] ‚Üí [0, ‚àû) which satisfies, for all Y ‚äÜùí≥ and all k ‚àà [K], 

    Œº(Y, k) ‚â• p^Y Q_k(Y) ‚àë_ùíØ a neighbor-set
    for Y‚àè_(Y',k') ‚àà TŒº(Y',k')

Then, the expected number of resamplings is at most ‚àë_(Y,k)Œº(Y,k).

(b) Suppose there exists Œº: 2^ùí≥√ó [K] ‚Üí [0, ‚àû) which satisfies, for all Y ‚äÜùí≥ and all k ‚àà [K], 

    Œº(Y, k) ‚â• p^Y Q_k(Y) ( ‚àè_Y' ‚àº Y (1 + ‚àë_k' ‚àà [K]Œº(Y', k')) ) ( 1 + ‚àë_Y‚Äù‚ãà_k YŒº(Y‚Äù, k)  )

Then, the expected number of resamplings is at most ‚àë_(Y,k)Œº(Y,k).

(c) Suppose that for all Y ‚àà 2^ùí≥, k ‚àà [K] we have p^Y Q_k(Y) ‚â§ P; and suppose that for all supported (Y,k), there are at most D supported (Y', k') with (Y', k') ‚âà (Y,k) (note that we allow here (Y', k') = (Y,k).) And suppose finally that we satisfy the criterion

    e P D ‚â§ 1

Then, the expected number of resamplings is at most e ‚àë_(Y,k) p^Y Q_k(Y).

Suppose we are given an assignment of non-negative real numbers Œª_x‚ààùêë_+ and coefficients a_x ‚àà [0,1] for each element x ‚ààùí≥. (Recall that an element x refers to an ordered pair (i,j), where i ‚àà [n] and j is a possible assignment to variable X_i)

Define Œº = ‚àë_x a_x Œª_x, and for each i ‚àà [n] define Œº_i  = ‚àë_j a_i,jŒª_i,j.

Suppose that there is a complex bad event ‚Ñ¨ defined by 
    ‚Ñ¨‚â°‚àë_x a_k [X_i = j] ‚â• t

where we use the Iverson notation for whether variable i takes on value j, where t ‚â•Œº.  Let d be any non-negative integer. Then, recalling Definition¬†<ref>, there is a fractional hitting-set Q with the property 

    G(Q, Œª) ‚â§Œº^d/d! td; ¬†¬†
    G_i(Q, Œª) ‚â§d Œº_i/Œº¬∑Œº^d/d! td.


We refer to the parameter d as the width of this hitting-set.

sentence:
Suppose that we have an LP parametrized by a_k,x, c_k, where D ‚â•max_x‚àë_k,x a_k,x.

Now let œµ‚àà [0,1], b_k ‚àà [1, ‚àû)^K satisfy the following conditions for all k ‚àà [K]


  (C1) (b_k+1/c_k (1 + œµ) - 1) Ch(c_k (1 + œµ), b_k) ‚â§œµ/4 D

  (C2) Ch(c_k (1 + œµ), b_k) ‚â§ 1/2


Then if the linear program 
    ‚àë_j ‚àà L_i z_i,j = 1,     ‚àë_x a_k,x z_x ‚â§ c_k,      z_x ‚àà [0,1]

is satisfiable, then so is the integer program

    X_i ‚àà L_j     ‚àë_i,j a_k,i,j [X_i = j] ‚â§ b_k


Furthermore, suppose we have a separation oracle for the LP and the IP. (That is, given a variable assignment, we can either find a violated linear constraint, or determine that all constraints are satisfied). Then such a satisfying assignment can be found in time which is polynomial in the number n of blocks.

Remark: Because of our convention that Ch(Œº, t) = 1 for t ‚â§Œº, then (C2) automatically implies b_k ‚â• c_k(1+œµ).

sentence:
Given an ordering of the children at each internal vertex, the vertices of a
complete k-ary tree with height m correspond naturally to the strings
of length at most m from the alphabet [k].  Define an edge-coloring œï
by letting the color of each edge from parent x to child y be the index of
y in the ordering of the children of x (note that œï is not a proper
coloring).  For a [k]-coloring f of the vertices of T, a full path P is an
f-path if the color of each non-leaf vertex on P equals the color
of the edge to its child on P.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a (d,r,g)-graph with a specified ordering of the d children at
each non-leaf vertex of the underlying tree T.  The corresponding
reduced (d,r,g)-graph H is obtained from G as follows: given the
coloring œï of E(G) from Definition¬†<ref>, form H from G by
deleting at each non-root internal vertex v of T the subtree under the
descending edge whose color under œï is the same as the color of the edge
to the parent of v.  Each non-leaf vertex of H‚à© T has degree d in T,
and œï is a proper edge-coloring of H‚à© T.

sentence:
A graph is a coalition graph if it admits an acyclic orientation such that every
induced P_4  abcd has the end-edges ab and cd oriented in the same way, that is,
every oriented P_4 is of type 2 or¬†3. Such an orientation is called a coalition orientation .

sentence:
A graph is an opposition graph if it admits an acyclic orientation such that every
induced P_4  abcd has the end-edges ab and cd
oriented in opposition, that is, every oriented P_4 is of type 0 or¬†1.
Such an orientation is called an opposition orientation .
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
A graph is a generalized opposition graph if it admits an orientation such that every oriented P_4 is of type 0 or 1. Such an orientation is called a
generalized opposition orientation .

sentence:
A decomposition of a connected graph G = (V, E) is a finite set of non-empty connected subgraphs G_i = (V_i, E_i), i = 1,‚Ä¶,n, n 
ge 2 such that:

1. Each subgraph G_i contains at least one edge.

2. Any two different subgraphs G_i, G_j have no common edges and no more than one common vertex.

3. ‚ãÉ_i=1^n V_i = V, ‚ãÉ_i=1^n E_i = E.

4. If we construct a graph H with its vertices being graphs G_i and there is an edge between G_i and G_j if and only if V_i ‚à© V_j ‚àÖ, then this graph is a connected tree. Graph H is called a graph of decomposition .

sentence:
An affine polyhedral complex consists of (i) a finite family Œ† of nonempty sets, called faces , (ii)
a family P_p, p ‚ààŒ†, of polyhedra, and (iii) a family œÄ_p:P_p ‚Üí p of bijections
satisfying the following conditions:


  * for each face F of P_p, p‚ààŒ†, there exists f ‚ààŒ† with œÄ_p(F)=f;

  * for all p,q ‚ààŒ† there exist faces F of P_p and G of P_q such that
p ‚ãÇ q =œÄ_p(F)=œÄ_q(G) and, furthermore, the restriction of œÄ_q^-1‚àòœÄ_p to F is an affine isomorphism of the polyhedra F and G.


We denote an affine polyhedral complex simply by Œ†, assuming that the polyhedra P_p
and the maps œÄ_p‚ààŒ†, are clear from the context.

|Œ†| stands for the support space ‚ãÉ_p‚ààŒ†p of Œ†, with the induced topology.

The maximal faces of Œ† will be called its facets .

We speak of a polytopal complex if the polyhedra P_p are polytopes and a conical complex if the polyhedra P_p are cones.

A simplicial complex is polytopal complex whose faces are simplices.

sentence:
Consider the set
V={ (a,b)‚àà√ó|(a,b)=1}
of lattice points in the first quadrant that are visible from the origin.

The Stern‚ÄìBrocot tree T is a binary tree structure on¬†V,
recursively defined as follows.
For each t‚àà V, let t^+ and t^- denote its positive parent and negative parent, respectively.
For the root node :=(1,1), let ^+:=(0,1) and ^-:=(1,0).

For t‚àà V with t^+ defined,
let its positive child t_+ be given by t_+=t+t^+.
The positive and negative parents of t_+ are given by (t_+)^+=t^+ and (t_+)^-=t, respectively.

Similarly, for t‚àà V with t^- defined,
its negative child t_- is given by t_-=t+t^-,
whose positive and negative parents are given by (t_-)^+=t and (t_-)^-=t^-, respectively.

Note that t=t^-+t^+ for t‚àà V.


For t‚àà V with t^+ defined,
consider the node s:=t^++t‚àà V.
Define the positive and negative parents of s as s^+:=t^+ and s^-:=t, respectively.
This node s is the positive child of t, denoted t_+.

Similarly, for t‚àà V with t^- defined,
the node s:=t^-+t‚àà V is the negative child of t, denoted t_-.
The positive and negative parents of s are s^+:=t and s^-:=t^-, respectively.
Note that t=t^-+t^+ for t‚àà V.


For each non-root t‚àà V, draw a positive edge (t,t_+) and a negative edge (t,t_-).
This establishes the binary tree structure¬†T.
Note that for a non-root t‚àà V, precisely one of (t^+,t) and (t^-,t) is an edge in¬†T.
By an abuse of notation, we write t‚àà T instead of t‚àà V.


The depth of an element t‚àà T is the distance d(t) in the tree from the root  to¬†t.

sentence:
A projective plane is a point-line incidence structure with the following three properties:


  (P1) Every two different points are contained in a unique line.

  (P2) Every two different lines intersect in exactly
one point.

  (P3) There are four points with the property that no three of them are
contained in a single line.

sentence:
Let us call a poset B dichotomial, if it is atomistic, and
for each œÉ‚àà B the set of atoms A(B) A(œÉ) has
the least upper bound, denoted h(œÉ), in B.
In other words the latter condition says that there exists an h(œÉ)‚àà B
such that œÉ‚à© h(œÉ)=‚àÖ and at the same time
œÉ‚à™ h(œÉ) contains all the atoms of B.
Clearly, h(h(œÉ))=œÉ, so there is defined an involution h B‚Üí B.
Clearly, the composition H BhBùïÄB^* is order-preserving.
In particular, every dichotomial poset B is isomorphic to its dual B^*.

sentence:
Suppose that K is a poset that is Y‚àá-transformable at some C‚àà K.
Then we define the Y‚àá-transform of K at C to be the poset K_C
that has one element BÃÇ for each B‚àà K and satisfies the following for
each A,A'‚àâ{C,D_1,D_2,D_3}:



  * ƒà>DÃÇ_i, i=1,2,3;


  * √Ç<DÃÇ_i iff A<D_i+1 or A<D_i-1;


  * √Ç<ƒà iff A<D_1 or A<D_2 or A<D_3;


  * √Ç>DÃÇ_i iff A>D_i+1 and A>D_i-1;


  * √Ç>ƒà iff A>D_1 and A>D_2 and A>D_3;


  * √Ç>√Ç' iff A>A'.


This definition immediately implies that (K_C)^* is Y‚àá-transformable
at (ƒà)^*.
A straightforward Boolean logic using that K is Y‚àá-transformable at C
shows further that the Y‚àá-transform of (K_C)^* at (ƒà)^* is
isomorphic to K^*.

We say that a poset L is ‚àáY-transformable at E‚àà L if L^* is
Y‚àá-transformable at E^*.
In that case the ‚àáY-transform of L at E is defined to be
the poset L^E ((L^*)_E^*)^*.

sentence:
A triple of type A is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere below b,
and the row containing a and b is at least as long as the row containing c.

Similarly, a triple of type B is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c,
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere above a,
and the row containing a and b is strictly longer than the row containing c.

A type A triple is an inversion triple if the entries ordered increasingly
form a counter-clockwise orientation. Similarly, a type B triple is an inversion triple
if the entries ordered increasingly form a clockwise orientation.
If two entries are equal, the one with the largest subscript in <ref>
is considered to be largest.

       [‚ãÆ] 
        c_2 
        Type B:  centertableaux,boxsize=1.2em

    [‚ãÆ]     
    
    a_3     b_1

sentence:
Let G be a triangulation of a surface  F^2 possibly with non-empty boundary. Let v_1v_2v_3 be
a cycle  of G such that deg(v_i)=4 for i=1, 2, 3 and
 {a_1, a_2, a_3}  be the only three vertices
such that a_i is adjacent to v_j and v_k for {i, j, k}={1,2,3}. The subgraph H‚äÇ
G induced by the vertex set {a_1, a_2, a_3, v_1, v_2, v_3} is said to be  an
 octahedron component  centered at
v_1v_2v_3 with remaining vertices a_1, a_2, a_3 if the cycle a_1a_2a_3 exists in G (and
hence in H) and one of the following conditions holds:



  * v_i‚àâ‚àÇ G for all i=1,2,3.

  *  Only one v_i lies in ‚àÇ G and ‚àÇ G coincides with
v_ia_ja_k.

  * Exactly v_i, v_j‚àà‚àÇ G and hence  ‚àÇ
G=v_iv_ja_k.

  * v_i‚àà‚àÇ G  for all i=1,2,3 and hence
‚àÇ G= v_iv_jv_k.

An octahedron component of G is said to be external if two edges a_ia_j, a_ja_k lie in
‚àÇ G (in particular, Œ¥(a_j)=4). Observe that this happens only under  condition 1.

Let  G‚àà‚Ñ±^2(4) be a triangulation of F^2.  A quasi-octahedron component of
G, ùí™, is said to be  removable in ‚Ñ±^2(4) (or
4-removable , for short) if one of the following conditions holds:


  * The graph G'=G-{v_1,  v_2,   v_3 } yields a triangulation of F^2 in ‚Ñ±^2(4).

  * The graph G'=(G-{v_i,  v_j })/a_iv_k, with v_k‚àà‚àÇ G,  yields a
triangulation of F^2 in ‚Ñ±^2(4).

 In both cases, we will simply say that G' is obtained by
removing a quasi-octahedron from G. Conversely, if case (1) happens, we say that G is
obtained from G' by  adding a quasi-octahedron along two boundary edges a_ia_3 (for
i=1, 2) of G'. In case (2) we say that G is obtained from G' by embedding a
quasi-octahedron in a boundary face a_1a_2a_3 of G'.

Here œÉ_i denotes the topological closure of œÉ_i and ‚âà denotes homeomorphism. Also ùîπ^l and ùïä^l are the l-dimensional closed unit ball and unit sphere, respectively. The underlying space |C| of C is the topological space œÉ_1 ‚à™‚ãØ‚à™œÉ_s.

sentence:
Let X^d be a cell complex, and let k‚â§ d.
A cellular spanning k-tree (for short, CST or k-CST) of
X is a k-dimensional subcomplex Y‚äÜ X such that
Y_(k-1) = X_(k-1) and
  
  
    _k(Y) = 0,
        |_k-1(Y)| < ‚àû,   and
        |Y_k| = |X_k| - _k(X) + _k-1(X).

  

We write _k(X) for the set of all k-CST's of X,
sometimes omitting the subscript if k=d.
Note that _k(X)=_k(X_(j)) for all j‚â• k.

sentence:
A shifted cubical complex is a proper cubical complex
X‚äÜ Q_n that satisfies
the following conditions for every f,g ‚àà{0,1,}^n
with f= g:



  *  X contains the full 1-skeleton of Q_n.


  *  If f ‚àà X and (f) = (g), then g ‚àà X.


  * 
If g ‚àà X and (f)_< precedes (g)_< in
component-wise partial order (that is, the i^th smallest element
of (f)_< is less than or equal to that of (g)_<
for every i), then f ‚àà X.

x_n^Œ±_n

 We denote by M_J(t,U) the set of

sentence:
Let U ‚äÇ be a finite set of terms; for each u ‚àà U, 1‚â§ i ‚â§ n  consider 
h_i(u,U)=max{_i(v):  v ‚àà U, _j(v)=_j(u),  i+1‚â§ j ‚â§ n}-_i(u) ‚àà.
If h_i(u,U)>0, define
k_i:=min{_i(v)-_i(u) : _j(v)=_j(u),  i+1‚â§ j ‚â§ n, _i(v)>_i(u)};
then x_i^k_i is called non-multipicative power of u ‚àà U.
We denote by NMP(u,U) the set of nonmultiplicative powers for u ‚àà U.

sentence:
Let U ‚äÇ be a finite set of terms and u ‚àà U; the elements in the monoid ideal 


    NM(u,U)={v ‚àà| ‚àÉ w ‚àà NMP(u,U):  w | v}

are called Janet-like nonmultipliers for u, whereas the elements in
M(u,U)=‚àñ NM(u,U) are called Janet-like multipliers for u.


A term u ‚àà U is a Janet-like divisor of w ‚àà if w=uv with v ‚àà M(u,U).

sentence:
A slice of a frieze pattern of type D_N is defined as follows.
We initially select an entry E_1 in the top row.
For 2‚â§ i‚â§ N-1, suppose that an entry E_i-1 in the
i-1st row has already been chosen. We select an entry E_i in the
ith row which is either immediately down and to the right of E_i-1
or immediately down and to the left of E_i-1.
In addition, we select an entry E_N in row N below the entry
immediately to the right of and below E_N-2 or below the entryimmediately to the left of and below E_N-2.

sentence: Let n be an even positive integer. A graph G with n vertices is a comb if the vertex set V(G) can be partitioned into two subsets of size n/2, V_1 and V_2, such that the induced subgraph on V_1 is a path, the induced subgraph on V_2 is an empty graph, and the edges between V_1 and V_2 form a perfect matching.

sentence:
A weak k-composition Œ≥ is a k-tuple of nonnegative integers 
(Œ≥_1, Œ≥_2, ‚Ä¶, Œ≥_k).  Each Œ≥_i (even if Œ≥_i=0) is called a part of Œ≥.  The weight of Œ≥, denoted |Œ≥|, is ‚àë_i=1^m Œ≥_i.

that j appears as a part in Œ≥:

    f_j(Œ≥) := #{ i : Œ≥_i = j }.
 
The frequency sequence associated with Œ≥ is

    f(Œ≥) := ( f_0(Œ≥), f_1(Œ≥), f_2(Œ≥), f_3(Œ≥), ‚Ä¶ ).

Following Schneider¬†<cit.>, for a partition Œª = (Œª_1, Œª_2, ‚Ä¶, Œª_k), we define its
   norm to be the product of its parts,
   
    Œª  := Œª_1 Œª_2 ‚ãØŒª_k.
  Further, the
 factorial of a partition Œª is Œª! = (Œª_1!, Œª_2!, ‚Ä¶, Œª_k!), so 
 that Œª = Œª_1! Œª_2! ‚ãØŒª_k!.
 Analogously for a weak k-composition Œ≥ = (Œ≥_1, ‚Ä¶, Œ≥_k),      
    Œ≥ := Œ≥_1! Œ≥_2! ‚Ä¶Œ≥_k!
  
      
  
 Observe that f effectively maps a partition Œª = (Œª_1, Œª_2, ‚Ä¶) 
 to a weak Œª_1-composition of weight l(Œª) if we ignore the infinite tail
 of zeros in f(Œª).
 For example, f( (5,5,5,5,3,2,2,1,1,1)) = (3,2,1,0,4), a weak 5-composition of weight
 10.
    Likewise, f 
maps a
 weak k-composition Œ≥ to a weak L-composition of weight k, where L is the
 largest part of Œ≥.
       Thus the  frequency factorial product of a weak k-composition Œ≥
may be consistently

    Œ≥ = f_0(Œ≥)! f_1(Œ≥)!  f_2(Œ≥)! ‚ãØ ,

     and that of a partition Œª as
     
    Œª = f_1(Œª)! f_2(Œª)! f_3(Œª)! ‚ãØ  .

A quasiorder ‚âæ on a set X is a binary relation

  * m_1(i)‚àº_P_3 m_1(j) if and only if i‚àº_P_1 j, and m_2(i)‚àº_P_3 m_2(j) if and only if i‚àº_P_2 j

  * i‚àà(P_3) if and only if there exists either a j‚àà(P_1) so that i=m_1(j) or a j‚àà(P_2) so that i=m_2(j)

  * i‚àà(P_3) if and only if there exists either a j‚àà(P_1) so that i=m_1(j) or a j‚àà(P_2) so that i=m_2(j)

  * (i,i')‚àà(P_3) if and only if there exists either a (j,j')‚àà(P_1) so that i=m_1(j) and i'=m_1(j') or a (j,j')‚àà(P_2) so that i=m_2(j) and i'=m_2(j')

Such a merge is denoted as m_1,m_2:P_1,P_2‚Üí P_3.

sentence:
Let G be a simple graph with n vertices, and L be a list assignment of V(G). For each vertex u‚àà V(G), let L_u={u}√ó L(u). For each edge uv in G, let M_uv be a matching (maybe empty) between the sets L_u and L_v and let ‚Ñ≥_L = { M_uv : uv ‚àà E(G)}, called the matching assignment . Let G_L be the graph that satisfies the following conditions



  * V(G_L) = ‚à™_u‚àà V(G) L_u.

  * for all u ‚àà V(G), the set L_u forms a clique.

  * if uv ‚àà E(G), then the edges between L_u and L_v are those of M_uv

  * if uv ‚àâ E(G), then there are no edges between L_u and L_v

If G_L contains an independent set of size n, then G has an ‚Ñ≥_L-coloring. The graph G is DP-k-colorable if, for each k-list assignment L and each matching assignment ‚Ñ≥_L over L, it has an ‚Ñ≥_L-coloring. The minimum k such that G is DP-k-colorable is the DP-chromatic number of G, denoted by œá_DP(G).

Let G be a looped simple graph and v a vertex of G.



  * The graph obtained from G by complementing the loop status of v is denoted G_‚Ñì^v.

  * The graph obtained from G by complementing the adjacency status of every pair of neighbors of v is the¬†simple local complement of G at v, denoted G_s^v.

  * The graph obtained from G by complementing the adjacency status of every pair of neighbors of v and the loop status of every neighbor of G is
 the¬†non-simple local complement of G at v, denoted G_ns^v.

  * The equivalence relation on looped simple graphs generated by loop complementations and local complementations is¬†local equivalence .

A vertex x ‚àà V is a simplicial vertex 
if the induced graph on N(x) is a clique; equivalently

sentence:
¬†


  * A dissection plane (of a given floor plan) is the union of a maximal set of faces that must have the same coordinate value. More precisely let us say that two faces are attached if their intersection has positive area. Taking the equivalence relation generated by this, dissection planes are exactly the unions of equivalence classes.

  * The dissection graph associated to a floor plan in a coordinate direction is an oriented graph. Its vertices are the dissection planes orthogonal to the given direction. For each block of the floor plan one draws an edge between the dissection planes containing the two faces of the block orthogonal to the given direction, and orients it towards the plane with the larger coordinate value.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Two floor plans are topologically equivalent if their dissection graphs are isomorphic.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence: We will also use a one-dimensional analogue of dissection planes. Similarly to faces, we can say that two edges (of two blocks) are attached if their intersection has positive length. Extending this to an equivalence relation, unions of the equivalence classes are going to be referred to as supporting segments . It is not hard to see (by looking at Figure¬†<ref>) that, when two edges are attached, they lie in the intersection of two perpendicular dissection planes.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Suppose we are given a floor plan with the blocks labeled from 1 to n. For each corner P of the host box, let T_P be a tree whose vertices are the blocks, and each block is connected by an edge to its unique parent with respect to P. Vertices are labeled 1 to n according to the numbers in the floor plan, and edges are labeled according to the type of the parent relation. The edge and vertex labeled tree constructed this way is called a corner tree of the floor plan. The tree has a unique root, the block that is adjacent to the corner P. It will also be useful to consider the corner tree without the vertex labels. This will be denoted by _P.

sentence:
The line ‚Ñí: ax+by+c=0 divides the Cartesian plane into two half-planes characterized by the sign of H(x,y)=ax+by+c. One of these half-planes satisfies ax+by+c>0 while the other half-plane satisfies ax+by+c<0. The line ax+by+c=0 is called the boundary of the half-planes. 

The set of points in the Cartesian plane which lie above the line forms the upper half-plane , and the set of points which lie below the line forms the lower half-plane . 

A test point , which lies on one side or the other of this line, is used to decide whether the solution of the inequality is the region above or below the straight line.

sentence:
We may split (or smooth ) a crossing in two ways such that either of the A-regions or the B-regions are respectively joined into the so-called A-channel and the B-channel . We say that a split is of type A or an A-split (correspondingly of type B or a B-split ) if it opens the A-channel (correspondingly the B-channel). The split process is illustrated in [fig:state-of-crossing]Figure <ref>fig:state-of-crossing.



    < g r a p h i c s >

The splits of a crossing.
		


A state for the diagram D is a diagram obtained by opening the A channel or the B channel at each crossing. The result is a union of mutually disjoint Jordan curves (or components). We let a k-state denote a state which consists of the union of k Jordan curves. Notice that the number of states of a  diagram with n crossings is then 2^n. For example, [fig:trefoil-decomposition]Figure <ref>fig:trefoil-decomposition displays the 2^3 states of the trefoil F_3 arranged in a binary tree. We then associate the enumeration of these states with the so-called states summation <cit.>.



    < g r a p h i c s >

The states for the trefoil diagram.

sentence:
[Samplers with respect to number of vertices]

Let n‚ààùêç be a target size.
An exact-size 
sampler A_n can be designed so as to generate 
labelled planar graphs with n vertices uniformly at
random. For any tolerance ratio œµ>0, an
approximate-size sampler  A_n,œµ can be designed so as to generate planar
graphs with their number of vertices in [n(1-œµ),n(1+œµ)], and following the 
 uniform distribution for each size k‚àà
[n(1-œµ),n(1+œµ)].  

Under a real-arithmetics complexity model, 
Algorithm A_n is of expected complexity O(n^2), and  
Algorithm A_n,œµ is of expected complexity O(n/œµ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Samplers with respect to the numbers of vertices and edges]

Let n‚ààùêç be a target size and Œº‚àà(1,3) be a parameter describing
the ratio edges-vertices.
An exact-size
sampler A_n,Œº can be designed so as to generate planar graphs with n vertices and ‚åäŒº n‚åã edges uniformly at
random. For any tolerance-ratio œµ>0, an
approximate-size sampler  A_n,Œº,œµ can be designed so as to generate  planar
graphs with their number of vertices in [n(1-œµ),n(1+œµ)] and their ratio edges/vertices in 
[Œº (1-œµ),Œº (1+œµ)], and following the 
 uniform distribution for each fixed pair (number of vertices,
number of edges).

Under a real-arithmetics complexity model, 
for a fixed Œº‚àà(1,3), Algorithm A_n,Œº is of expected complexity O_Œº(n^5/2). For fixed constants Œº‚àà(1,3) and œµ>0,

sentence:
For a partition Œª, we label boxes of Œª as locked by the following procedure:


  * If a box x has a locked box directly above it (or is on the first row) and every unoccupied space in the same ladder as x, lying below x, has an unoccupied space directly above it then x is locked. Boxes locked for this reason are called type I locked boxes.

  * If a box y is locked, then every box to the left of y in the same row is also locked. Boxes locked for this reason are called type II locked boxes.


Boxes which are not locked are called unlocked .

sentence:
The collection of reduced words R(w) has a circuit if there exists a sequence of elements in R(w), say

    ùêÆ_0, ùêÆ_1, ùêÆ_2, ‚Ä¶, ùêÆ_2ùê≠ = ùêÆ_0

for some integer t such that for all s, either

    ùêÆ_2ùê¨, ùêÆ_2ùê¨+1‚àà B_s  and
       ùêÆ_2ùê¨+1, ùêÆ_2ùê¨+2‚àà C_s

or

    ùêÆ_2ùê¨, ùêÆ_2ùê¨+1‚àà C_s  and
       ùêÆ_2ùê¨+1, ùêÆ_2ùê¨+2‚àà B_s

where B_s ‚àà B(w) and C_s ‚àà C(w). 
Equivalently, define a graph Œì(w) whose vertices are B(w) ‚à™ C(w), with an edge between B_i and C_j if and only if B_i ‚à© C_j ‚â†‚àÖ; then R(w) has a circuit if the graph Œì(w) contains a circuit, i.e., if there is some vertex v in Œì(w) such that one can travel from v to itself following a nontrivial sequence of edges and vertices. Equivalently, R(w) has a circuit if and only if Œì(w) is not a tree.

E(C^i_6,k_i)={a^ia^i_j, a^i_jb^i_j, b^i_jb^i :1 ‚â§ j ‚â§ k_i}. 
A hexagonal strip H(k_1, d_1, k_2, d_2, ‚Ä¶, k_n-1, d_n-1, k_n) is the graph obtained by gluing together C^1_6,k_1, ‚Ä¶, C^n_6,k_n in such a way that the edge b^i_2b^i is glued to a^i+1a^i+1_1 and the direction is described by d_i:

sentence:
[inverse, undirected, complement, oriented, transitive]¬†




  * The inverse of an edge (a,b) is the edge (a,b)^-1=(b,a).
The inverse of a graph G=(V,E) is the graph G^-1=(V,E^-1), where E^-1={(a,b)^-1| (a,b)‚àà E}.

  * We say that a graph G=(V,E) is undirected iff E=E^-1.
The undirected closure of a graph G=(V,E) is the graph ùí∞(G)=(V,E‚à™ E^-1).

  * The complement of G=(V,E) is the graph G=(V,V V‚àñ E), where V V={(a,b)| a,b‚àà V, a‚â† b}.
The undirected complement G of G is the complement of ùí∞(G).

  * A graph G=(V,E) is oriented iff E‚à© E^-1=‚àÖ.
A graph G'=(V,E') is an orientation of G=(V,E) iff E' is a maximal oriented subset of E.

  * A graph G=(V,E) is transitive iff for all edges (a,b),(b,c)‚àà E with a‚â† c we also have (a,c)‚àà E.
The transitive closure of a graph G=(V,E) is G=(V,E), where E is the minimal transitive superset of E.

[child quotient graph]¬†





  * We denote the minimal strong module containing a module M by M^+.

sentence:
‚ÄúBreaking‚Äù cutvertices.  
Suppose the deletion of a cutvertex would result in more than one component, each of which contains a cycle (when including the cutvertex).  Also suppose that there is exactly one component that has an odd number of vertices (not including the cutvertex).  The operation called ‚Äúbreaking‚Äù the cutvertex from a graph will mean deleting all edges incident with the cutvertex except for those in the odd component.  A graph is ‚Äúbroken‚Äù if there are no more cutvertices.

sentence:
A graph is an ordered pair G = (V, E) comprising a set V of vertices and a set E ‚äÜ V √ó V of edges.
We often denote by V(G) and E(G) the set of vertices and the set of edges of a graph G, respectively.

sentence:
Let G = (V, E) and G' = (V', E') be graphs.
A mapping h  V ‚Üí V' is a homomorphism of G to G', denoted h  G ‚Üí G', if h maps edges to edges, i.e., for all u, v ‚àà V, (u,v) ‚àà E implies (h(u), h(v)) ‚àà E'.
A homomorphism h  G ‚Üí G' is strong if, in addition, it maps nonedges to nonedges, i.e., for all u, v ‚àà V, (u,v) ‚àâ E implies (h(u), h(v)) ‚àâ E'.
In other words, h  V ‚Üí V' is a strong homomorphism if for all u, v ‚àà V, (u,v) ‚àà E if and only if (h(u), h(v)) ‚àà E'.
If h  G ‚Üí G' is surjective (and strong), then G' is called a strong homomorphic image of G.

sentence:
Let T(X) be the set of all terms of type (2,0) over a set X of variables, using juxtaposition as the binary operation symbol and ‚àû as the unary operation symbol.
In other words, T(X) is defined inductively as follows:


  *  Every x ‚àà X is a term, and ‚àû is a term.

  *  If t_1 and t_2 are terms, then (t_1 t_2) is a term.

  * T(X) is the set of all terms which can be obtained from <ref> and <ref> in finitely many steps.


Unless otherwise mentioned, we assume that X is the standard set of variables {x_1, x_2, x_3, ‚Ä¶}.
The set of variables occurring in a term t is denoted by (t).
The leftmost variable occurring in t is denoted by L(t).
A term is called trivial if it contains an occurrence of the symbol ‚àû.

sentence:
An assignment of values in a graph algebra G for the variables X is a map h  X ‚Üí V(G) ‚à™{‚àû}, which will be denoted for brevity by h  X ‚ÜíG.
Any assignment h  X ‚ÜíG extends to a map ƒ• T(X) ‚Üí V(G) ‚à™{‚àû} (or briefly ƒ• T(X) ‚ÜíG) as

    ƒ•(t) =
    
    h(x),    if t = x ‚àà X,
    ‚àû,    if t = ‚àû,
    ƒ•(t_1) ¬∑ƒ•(t_2),    if t = (t_1 t_2).

For notational simplicity, we write h(t) for ƒ•(t), and we call h(t) the value of t under the assignment h.
The value of t under h obviously depends only on the restriction of h to (t);
hence we can define the value of t under a map h'  S ‚Üí T with (t) ‚äÜ S ‚äÜ X and T ‚äÜ V(G) ‚à™{‚àû} by taking an arbitrary extension h  X ‚ÜíG of h' and setting h'(t) := h(t).

sentence:
To every nontrivial term t ‚àà T(X) we assign a directed graph G(t) = (V(t), E(t)), where V(t) := (t) and E(t) is defined inductively as


  * E(t) = ‚àÖ if t = x for some x ‚àà X,

  * E(t) = E(t_1) ‚à™ E(t_2) ‚à™{ (L(t_1), L(t_2)) } if t = (t_1 t_2).

Note that G(t) is always a connected graph and all its vertices are reachable from L(t).
In fact, a finite graph G is isomorphic to G(t) for some term t if and only if there is a vertex a ‚àà V(G) such that [G]a = V(G) (see <cit.>).
We call such graphs term graphs.
Observe that every (strong) homomorphic image of a term graph is a term graph.

sentence:
Pairs (Œ±, Œ≤) ‚ààùí´_fin((X)) √ó(X) are called implications or quasiidentities (or universal Horn clauses ; see Wechler¬†<cit.>) and they are normally written as Œ±‚ÜíŒ≤.
The finite set Œ± of identities and the identity Œ≤ are called the premise and the consequence of the implication, respectively.
If Œ± = {s_1 ‚âà t_1, ‚Ä¶, s_n ‚âà t_n} and Œ≤ = s ‚âà t, we can write Œ±‚ÜíŒ≤ as (s_1 ‚âà t_1 ‚àß‚Ä¶‚àß s_n ‚âà t_n) ‚Üí s ‚âà t.
We denote the set of all implications by (X).

A graph G or a graph algebra G satisfies an implication Œ±‚ÜíŒ≤ if for all assignments h  X ‚ÜíG we have

    ( ‚àÄ s_i ‚âà t_i ‚ààŒ± h(s_i) = h(t_i) )
    
    h(s) = h(t).

We write

    G Œ±‚ÜíŒ≤  or  GŒ±‚ÜíŒ≤

if G satisfies Œ±‚ÜíŒ≤.
Note that every identity can be viewed as an implication, because G  t ‚âà t' if and only if G ‚àû‚âà‚àû‚Üí t ‚âà t'.

sentence:
The satisfaction relation between graphs and identities induces a Galois connection in the usual way, and the associated mappings, denoted by  and , are defined as follows.
For any set ùí¶ of graphs and any set Œ£ of identities, let

    Œ£    := { G ‚ààùí¢|‚àÄ t ‚âà t' ‚ààŒ£ G  t ‚âà t' }, 
    ùí¶    := { t ‚âà t' ‚àà(X) |‚àÄ G ‚ààùí¶ G  t ‚âà t' }.

A set ùí¶ of graphs is called a graph variety if ùí¶ = Œ£ for some set Œ£ of identities, or, equivalently, if ùí¶ = ùí¶.
A set Œ£ of identities is called an equational theory of graphs if Œ£ = ùí¶ for some set ùí¶ of graphs, or, equivalently, if Œ£ = Œ£.
In other words, the Galois closed sets are the graph varieties and equational theories of graphs.

Similarly, the satisfaction relation between graphs and implications induces a Galois connection given by the mappings  and  defined as follows.
For any set ùí¶ of graphs and any set Œ£ of implications, let

    Œ£    := { G ‚ààùí¢|‚àÄŒ±‚ÜíŒ≤‚ààŒ£ G Œ±‚ÜíŒ≤}, 
    ùí¶    := {Œ±‚ÜíŒ≤‚àà(X) |‚àÄ G ‚ààùí¶ G Œ±‚ÜíŒ≤}.

A set ùí¶ of graphs is called a graph quasivariety if ùí¶ = Œ£ for some set Œ£ of implications, or, equivalently, if ùí¶ = ùí¶.
A set Œ£ of implications is called an implicational theory of graphs if Œ£ = ùí¶ for some set ùí¶ of graphs, or, equivalently, if Œ£ = Œ£.
In other words, the Galois closed sets are the graph quasivarieties and implicational theories of graphs.

For a set Œ£ of implications, denote by Œ£ the set of all finite graphs in Œ£.

sentence:

sentence:
The coding rate R of a Sudoku can be described as an error correcting code by 
  
    R = log_n^2 S/C,

  where S and C denote the number of solutions to the Sudoku 
  and the number of cells in the Sudoku grid, respectively.

sentence:
The representation with a minimum total number of terms
among all possible representations of Ex(FG) derived by the decomposition
method is achieved if and only if in each recursive step i is equal to q+p/2 for odd q-p+1 and to q+p-1/2 or q+p+1/2
for even q-p+1, i.e., when i is a middle vertex of the interval (p,q).
Such a decomposition method is called optimal .

sentence:
An algebraic expression is called an st-dag expression (a 
factoring of an st-dag in <cit.>) if it is algebraically equivalent to
the canonical expression of an st-dag. An st-dag expression consists of
terms (edge labels), the operators + (disjoint union) and ¬∑
(concatenation, also denoted by juxtaposition when no ambiguity arises), and
parentheses.

sentence:
We define the complexity of an algebraic expression in two ways.
The complexity of an algebraic expression is (i) the total number of terms
in the expression including all their appearances ( the first
complexity characteristic ) or (ii) the number of plus operators in the
expression ( the second complexity characteristic ).

sentence:
A series-parallel graph is defined recursively so that a
single edge is a series-parallel graph and a graph obtained by a parallel or
a series composition of series-parallel graphs is series-parallel.

We call these numbers parameters and we call A := {a_ij} a parameter list . The bigraphical arrangement Œ£_G(A) is the set of 2|E| hyperplanes,

    Œ£_G(A) := {x_i - x_j = a_ij{v_i,v_j}‚àà E}.

The regions of Œ£_G(A) are the connected components of ‚Ñù^n‚àñŒ£_G(A). The central region is the region defined by x_i - x_j < a_ij for all {v_i,v_j}‚àà E. The above condition on A guarantees that the central region is nonempty.

sentence: A partial orientation of G is a choice of directions for a subset of the edges of G.  Formally, a step is an ordered pair (u,v) ‚àà V√ó V such that¬†, and a partial orientation ùí™ is a set of steps with the property that if (u,v)‚ààùí™, then (v,u)‚àâùí™. sentence: Let¬†ùí™ be a partial orientation.  If e={u,v}‚àà E and (u,v)‚ààùí™, then despite the ambiguity, we write e‚ààùí™ and say e is oriented .  In that case, we think of¬†e as an arrow from u to v and write¬†e^-=u and¬†e^+=v.  If neither (u,v) nor (v,u) is in ùí™, we write e‚àâùí™ and say that e is an unoriented or blank edge.  The indegree of u‚àà V relative to¬†ùí™, denoted¬†indeg_ùí™(u), is the number of edges¬†e‚ààùí™ such that e^+=u.  Similarly, the outdegree of the vertex u‚àà V relative to ùí™ is the number of edges e‚ààùí™ such that e^-=u.  The degree of u is the number of e‚àà E containing u.

sentence: A parking function c = ‚àë_i=1^n c_i v_i of G_ with respect to¬†v_0 is an element of ‚Ñ§V such that for every non-empty subset W ‚äÜ V, there exists v_i ‚àà W with 0 ‚â§ c_i < d_W(v_i), where d_W(v_i) is the number of edges¬†e = {v_i,u}‚àà E_ with u ‚àà V_‚àñ W. sentence:
The following procedure is called the Pak-Stanley labeling of a bigraphical arrangement. It labels each region with an element of ‚Ñ§V. Label the central region of Œ£_G(A) with 0.  Put the central region in a queue,¬†Q.  Then, as long as Q is not empty:

  
  * Remove the first region R from Q.

sentence: A simple game is said to proper if for each complementary pair A, A^c of coalitions, at most one is winning; otherwise it is improper .  A simple game is said to be strong if for each complementary pair A, A^c of coalitions, at least one is winning.  A simple game is said to be self-dual if for each complementary pair A, A^c of coalitions, precisely one is winning, i.e., if it is both proper and strong.

sentence:
[Nice separation]
  A separation¬†(A, B) of order two in a triangulated disk is called nice if A ‚à© B¬†is an edge in¬†G whose endpoints are both in¬†L_1. A separation¬†(A,B) of order three is called nice if there are exactly two vertices in¬†A ‚à© B ‚à© L_1, the vertex in (A ‚à© B) ‚àñ L_1 is a common neighbor of the vertices in¬†A ‚à© B ‚à© L_1, and furthermore, the three-vertex path¬†P in¬†G[A ‚à© B] with endpoints in¬†L_1 divides the region enclosed by¬†L_1 into a region¬†R_A containing precisely the vertices in¬†A and a region¬†R_B containing precisely the vertices in¬†B.

sentence:
[Separations induced by paths]
  Let u, w ‚àà L_1 such that {u, w}‚àà E(G).  The edge¬†{u, w} splits the closed region¬†R of the plane delimited by¬†L_1 into two closed regions¬†R_1, R_2, whose boundaries overlap on {u, w}.  We say that {u, w} induces a nice separation¬†(A,B) of order two, where one of its sides (, A or B) consists of the vertices in¬†R_1 and the other side of those in¬†R_2. Similarly, a (not necessarily induced) path¬†P:=(u, v, w) such that u, w ‚àà L_1 and v ‚àâ L_1, splits¬†R into two regions¬†R_1, R_2, whose boundaries overlap on P.  We say that P¬†induces a nice separation¬†(A,B) of order three, one of its sides consists of the vertices in¬†R_1 and the other of those in¬†R_2.

sentence:
[Linear, hinged, and homogenous sequences]
  We extend the definitions of triangular, L_1-nontrivial, and pointing left or right, to sequences of separations in a natural way: For some property Œ†‚àà{linear, hinged, homogeneous}, a sequence¬†is¬†Œ† (, satisfies Œ†) if each separation in¬†is¬†Œ†. Moreover, a sequence¬†of separations is
  [ homogeneous ]
  
   linear  if, for each pair¬†(A, B), (A', B') of consecutive separations in , we have A ‚ää A' and B ‚äã B';
  
   hinged  if it is triangular and if, for each pair (A, B), (A', B') of separations in¬†, we have A ‚à© B ‚à© L_1 = A' ‚à© B' ‚à© L_1; and
  
   homogeneous  if it is hinged and either points left or points right (in particular, is L_1-nontrivial and triangular).

sentence:
[Convention on basepoints]
Suppose Y‚äÜ^n is a based digital image with basepoint y_0 = (y_1, ‚Ä¶, y_n).  In any subdivision S(Y, k) of Y we may take y_0‚àà  S(y_0, k)‚äÜ S(Y, k) as the basepoint, where y_0 denotes the point whose coordinates are


    y_0=  (2ky_1 + k-1, ‚Ä¶, 2ky_n + k-1)     in  S(Y, 2k)
    ( (2k+1)y_1 + k, ‚Ä¶, (2k+1)y_n + k)     in  S(Y, 2k+1).


In an odd subdivision, y_0 is the centre point of S(y_0, 2k+1), which is a cubical  lattice in ^n, each side of which contains 2k+1 points.  In an even subdivision, S(y_0, 2k) does not have a centre point, as such, since there is no middle point in an interval which contains 2k points.  Rather, y_0 is a corner of the central clique of  S(y_0, 2k), which is to say a unit cubical  lattice in ^n that may be considered as the center of S(y_0, 2k).  Usually, and unless there is some reason not to do so, we will choose  y_0 as the basepoint of a subdivision S(Y, k).   One exception to this is  our convention that 0 ‚àà I_N is the basepoint of an interval. This means that when we  subdivide an interval, the basepoint of S(I_N, k) = I_Nk+k-1 will be 0 rather than 0 = k.   However we choose the basepoint in a subdivision, so long as we have the basepoint of S(Y, k) to be some point in S(y_0, k) ‚äÜ S(Y, k), then the standard projection œÅ_k  S(Y, k) ‚Üí Y is a based map.  In particular, note  that we have œÅ_k(y_0) = y_0.   Furthermore, with our convention that y_0 is the basepoint of S(Y, k), the partial projections œÅ^c_k S(Y, k) ‚Üí S(Y, k-1) for each k ‚â• 3 of def: rho^c are also based maps.  Indeed, from the formulas of def: rho^c, for
œÅ^c_2k+1 S(Y, 2k+1) ‚Üí S(Y, 2k), with k‚â• 1,  we have


    œÅ^c_2k+1(y_0)    = œÅ^c_2k+1( (2k+1)y_1 + k, ‚Ä¶, (2k+1)y_n + k )  
       = (2ky_1 + k-1, ‚Ä¶, 2ky_n + k-1) = y_0‚àà S(Y, 2k).


On the other hand, for
œÅ^c_2k S(Y, 2k) ‚Üí S(Y, 2k-1), with k‚â• 2,  we have


    œÅ^c_2k(y_0)    = œÅ^c_2k( 2ky_1 + k-1, ‚Ä¶, 2ky_n + k -1)  
       = ((2k-1)y_1 + k-1, ‚Ä¶, (2k-1)y_n + k-1) = y_0‚àà S(Y, 2k-1),


with this last identification following from the above definition of y_0‚àà S(Y, 2k-1) because we have 2k-1 = 2(k-1)+1.   In all cases, that is, we have
œÅ^c_k(y_0) = y_0, and  œÅ^c_k is a based map.

sentence:
[Nondeterministic Read-once branching programs (NROBPs).]
Let V be a set of Boolean variables.
Let Z be a directed acyclic graph (DAG) with one source and one sink so that some
of the edges are labelled with literals of V.
We say that v ‚àà V occurs on edge e is Z is Z is labelled with a literal
of v. The occurrence can be positive or negative if the labelling literal
is v and v, respectively.

We say that Z is a nondeterministic read-once branching program (NROBP) implementing a function
on V if each variable of V occurs exactly once [The requirement of
exactly one occurrence rather than at most one means that the NROBP is uniform. Since it is known that every
NROBP can be simulated by a uniform one with only a polynomial increase of the number of nodes (see e.g. <cit.>),
we assume the uniformity w.l.o.g.] on each source-sink path of Z.

For a path P of Z we denote by A(P) the set of literals labelling P and Var(A(P)) is denoted by Var(P).
Then the set of satisfying assignments of the function represented by Z consists of all A(P) 
such that P is a source-sink path of Z.

sentence:
[Partial matching width]
Let G be a graph and let V ‚äÜ V(G).
The partial matching width of V (w.r.t. G)
is the largest k such that any permutation SV of V
has a prefix SV' such that there is a matching of size at least
k between SV' and the rest of of G.

sentence:
[Witnessing matching]
Let V ‚äÜ V(G) and let SV be a permutation of V.
Let {u,v}‚àà E(G). Then {u,v} is supported
by a partition SV_1,SV_2 into a prefix and a suffix if 
either (i) say, u ‚àà SV_1 and v ‚àà SV_2 or (ii) say, u ‚àà SV, v ‚àà V(G) ‚àñ V.
A matching M is supported by SV_1,SV_2 is every edge of M is supported
by SV_1,SV_2.

A matching M is witnessing for SV if there is a partition of SV into a prefix
SV_1 and a suffix SV_2 supporting M.

sentence:
[Decision tree]
Let F be a function that is not constant zero.
Then a decision tree T for F is defined as follows.
Suppose that Var(F)={x}.
Then the root rt of T is labelled with x. If both {x} and { x} are satisfying
assignments of F then rt has two outgoing edges labelled with x and x, respectively
(the leaves are not labelled with variables).
If the only satisfying assignment of F is {x} then the only outgoing edge of rt is labelled
with x. Finally, if the only satisfying assignment of rt is { x} then the only outgoing edge
is labelled with x.

Now, assume that |Var(F)|>1. Let x ‚àà Var(F).
Label rt with x. If both x and x occur in satisfying assignments
of F then rt has two outgoing edges labelled with x and x.
Let u_1 and u_2 be the respective heads of these edges.
Then the subtree of T rooted by u_1 is a decision tree for F|_x
and the subtree rooted by u_2 is a decision tree for F|_ x.

If there is exactly one ‚Ñì‚àà{x, x} in the satisfying assignments of F then
there is only one outgoing edge labelled with ‚Ñì
and the subtree rooted by the head of this edge is a decision tree for F|_‚Ñì.

For a path P of T, we denote (similarly to NROBPs) by A(P) the set of literals
labelling the edges of P.

sentence:
[Solutiion counting decision tree]
A solution counting decision tree (SCDT) T for F is a decision
tree for F whose edges are associated with weights defined as follows.
Let rt be the root of T and let e be an outgoing edge of rt labelled
with a literal ‚Ñì. Then the weight of e is |F|_‚Ñì|/|F|.

Let u be an internal node of T and let P be the unique rt-u path of P
Let e be an outgoing edge of u and let ‚Ñì be the literal labelling e.
Then the weight of e is |F|_A(P) ‚à™{‚Ñì}|/|F|_A(P)|

The weight of a path of T is the product of weights of its edges.
The weight of an edge e is denoted by weight(e), the weight of a path
P is denoted by weight(P). Finally if P is a set of paths then
the weight of P, denoted by weight( P), is the sum of weights of paths
in P.

sentence:
Given a shifted semistandard tableau T of straight shape Œª and a letter a‚àà{1',1,2',2,3',3,‚Ä¶}, the mixed insertion of a into T is the tableau formed by the following process.
																																																																															
																																																																																
  * Insert a into the first row R_1, i.e., let b be the leftmost entry of R_1 for which a‚â∫_row b.  If there is no such b then place a at the end of row R_1 and stop the process. Otherwise, replace b with a and `bump out' b. If b was the leftmost entry in the row, proceed to step 2; otherwise, repeat step 1, inserting b into the next row.
																																																																																
  * Insert b into the next column to its right, bumping out the topmost entry y for which b‚â∫_col y, or placing b at the bottom of the column if y does not exist. Repeat step 2 (inserting y into the following column) until the process terminates.

sentence:
[Leaves, Bare Paths, and Levels]
Let¬†T be a tree. A leaf of¬†T is a vertex of degree one in¬†T. A bare path is a path in¬†T whose vertices have all degree two in¬†T. If we remove all leaves from¬†T, we call the leaves and bare paths in the remaining tree second level leaves and second level bare paths , respectively.  For distinction, we call the leaves and bare paths of the original tree¬†T also first level leaves and first level bare paths .

Let G and H be two graphs. A proper edge-coloring c:E(G) ‚Üí‚Ñï of G is called H-good if
 
 
  * G contains a rainbow copy of H and
 
  * for every edge e of color i there are edges e_1,‚Ä¶,e_i-1 incident to e such that c(e_j) = j for j = 1,‚Ä¶,i-1.
 
 A graph G is called H-good if it admits an H-good coloring.

sentence:
Let G be an edge-colored bipartite graph with V(G)=X‚äî Y.


  * G is  monochromatic if all edges in E(X,Y) are colored by the same color. 

  * G is  weakly X-canonical if E(x,Y) is monochromatic for each x‚àà X. 

  * G is X-canonical if it is weakly X-canonical
and for all distinct x,x'‚àà X the colors used on E(x,Y) and E(x',Y) are all different.

 In all these cases, the color z_x of the edges in E(x,Y) is called a canonical color .

We define the coloration X to be the sequence X=(x_i)_i=1^‚àû of non‚Äìnegative integers, where any x_i is the number of colors of the part i. If x_i=0, it means that we do not use the integer i in the compositions. Moreover, we define


  * L(X) as the set of all colored compositions with coloration X; we call an element of this set a composition (for shortness) and indicate it with bold letters, e.g., b‚àà L(X)

  * L_n(X) as the set of colored compositions of n with coloration X

  * A_n(X) = | L_n(X) |; A=A(X)=(A_n(X))_n=1^‚àû is the sequence of the number of colored compositions of n with coloration X, for n=1,2,‚Ä¶

  * P_n(X) = ‚àë_b‚àà L_n(X) p(b)

  * r(b) = p(b)+1 as the number of break‚Äìpoints

  * R_n(X) = ‚àë_b‚àà L_n(X) r(b)

sentence:
<cit.>
	Given p,p'‚ààùí´^‚àò‚àô_2,nb and sectors S in p and S' in p', we number the points in (S) and (S') with respect to the cyclic order. We say that (p,S) and (p',S') are equivalent if the following four conditions are met:
	
		
  * The sectors S and S' are of equal size.
		
  * The same normalized colors occur in the same order in S and S'.
		
  * For all i, the i-th point of S belongs to a block crossing ‚àÇ S in p if and only if the i-th point of S' belongs to a block crossing ‚àÇ S' in p'. 
		
  * For all i,j, the i-th and j-th points of S form a block in p if and only if the i-th and j-th points of S' form a block in p'.
                
                In other words: p restricted to S coincides with p' restricted to S' (up to rotation).

    Let  p be a bracket with lower row S.

  *  We call p residual of the second kind if p is connected and dualizable and if (S) contains exactly one turn of p.
    
  *  We call p residual if p is residual of the first or the second kind.
    
  
  * The set of all residual brackets is denoted by ‚Ñ¨_res.

* A bracket pattern is a non-empty finite subset of  and w denotes its largest element, its frame .
    
  * We define three operations on bracket patterns w, w'.
  
  
  * Let the superposition  of w and w' be given simply by union of sets, 
    w‚à™ w':= {i| i‚àà w or i‚àà w'}.

  
  * For all j‚àà w, denote by 
    ‚à©_jw:={i| i ‚àà w, i‚â§ j}
 the j-projection of w .
  
  * Lastly, define the dual of w by 
    w^‚Ä†:={w-i| i‚àà‚Ñï_0, i<w,i‚àâ w }.
    
  

  * A set ùîö of bracket patterns is called a bracket pattern category if it is closed under superposition, dualisation and projections in the above sense.

  * For every set ùîö of bracket patterns, denote by ùîö the bracket pattern category generated by ùîö. If ùîö={w} for a bracket pattern w, we slightly abuse notation by writing w instead of {w}.

A quaternary quantum  stabilizer code is an additive quaternary code ùíû 
contained in its dual ùíû^, where the duality is with respect to the symplectic form (see  <ref>).

sentence:
A quantum code  ùíû with parameters n,k,d ([[n,k,d]]-code), where k>0, 
is a quaternary quantum stabilizer code of binary dimension n-k satisfying the following: 
any codeword of ùíû^ having weight at most d-1 is in ùíû.

The code is pure if ùíû^ does not contain codewords of weight < d, 
equivalently if ùíû^ has strength t ‚â• d-1.

An [[n,0,d]]-code ùíû is a self-dual quaternary quantum stabilizer code of strength 
t=d-1.

sentence:
We call configuration (or n-configuration ) to
    a (2√ó n)-rectangle where exactly n of the 2n slots are
    painted with one of two colors, with the restriction that columns
    with both colors do not exist. The pair (i,j) for a
    (i+j)-configuration R with i slots colored with color one
    and j slots colored with color two (or i slots filled with
     and j slots filled with ) is the type of
    R.  The columns with no colored slots are empty
      columns and the columns with two colored slots
    towers . Both are called even columns and the columns
    with exactly one colored slot are called odd .  A
    type (i,j) configuration is ordered if the i slots with
    color one belong to the leftmost (2√ó i)-subrectangle and
    the j slots of color two belong to the complementary (2√ó
    j)-subrectangle. Finally, the set of ordered n-configurations
    is denoted ùí™_n and the set of n-configurations
    without towers is denoted ùíØ_n.

sentence:
Let a=a_0a_1, b=b_0b_1, be a pair of points, and
let the interval I = a_1b_1 be the body of
a horizontal barrier B.
For an interval J = a_0b_0 
we say that J is a vertical hole passing through B, 
or fitting  B, if a b within the rectangle
J√óa_1b_1.
For technical convenience, we also require |J|‚â§^-1|I|.
Consider a point u_0u_1 with u_i‚â§ a_i, i=0,1.
The hole J is called good as seen from point u if a is H-clean in
^‚Üí(u,a), and b is upper-right rightward
H-clean (recall Definition¬†<ref>). 
It is good if it is good as seen from any such point u.
Note that this way the horizontal cleanness is required to be strong, but no
vertical cleanness is required (since the barrier B was not required to

Each hole is called lower left clean, upper right clean, and so on,
if the corresponding rectangle is.

sentence:
[Complex two-dimensional sorts of cleanness]
We say that point u is clean in Q when
it is trap-clean in Q and its projections are clean in the
corresponding projections of Q.

If u is clean in all such left-open rectangles
then it is called upper right rightward clean.
We delete the ‚Äúrightward‚Äù qualifier here
if we have closed rectangles in the definition here instead of
left-open ones.
Cleanness with qualifier ‚Äúupward‚Äù is defined similarly.
Cleanness of v in Q and lower left cleanness of v are
defined similarly, using (u,v, -1, '),
except that the qualifier is unnecessary: all our rectangles are upper
right closed.

A point is called clean if it is upper right clean and lower left clean.
If both the lower left and upper right 
points of a rectangle Q are clean in Q then Q is called inner clean.
If the lower left endpoint is lower left clean and the upper
right endpoint is upper right rightward clean 
then Q is called outer rightward clean.
Similarly for outer upward clean and outer-clean.

We will also use a partial versions of cleanness.
If point u is trap-clean in Q and its projection on the x axis 
is strongly clean in the same projection of Q
then we will say that u is H-clean in Q.
Clearly, if u is H-clean in Q and its projection on the y axis is
clean in (the projection of) Q then it is clean in Q.
We will call rectangle Q inner H-clean if both its lower left and upper
right corners are H-clean in it.
It is now clear what is meant for example by a point 
being upper right rightward H-clean.

The notion V-clean is defined similarly when we interchange horizontal and
vertical.

sentence:
(Tutte) <cit.> Let M be a matroid.

i) M is binary (i.e. representable over ùîΩ_2) iff M has no U_2,4 minor (i.e. no minor of M is isomorphic to U_2,4).

ii) M is regular (i.e. representable over any field) iff M has no U_2,4, F_7, or F_7^* minor.

iii) M is graphic iff M has no U_2,4, F_7, F_7^*, M(K_5)^*, or M(K_3,3)^* minor.

Here U_2,4 is the uniform matroid of rank 2 on 4 elements, and F_7 is the Fano matroid.

sentence:
<cit.>.

A Boolean function f : _2^m _2 is bent
if its Hada¬≠mard transform has constant magnitude.
Specifically:

 
  * The Sylvester Hada¬≠mard matrix H_m, of order 2^m,
is defined by

    H_1    :=
    [
    [ 1 1; 1 - ]],
    
    
    H_m    := H_m-1‚äó H_1,   for   m > 1.



  * For a Boolean function f : _2^m _2,
define the vector f by

    f   := [(-1)^f[0], (-1)^f[1], ‚Ä¶, (-1)^f[2^m-1]]^T,

where the value of f[i], i ‚àà_2^m is given by the value of f on the binary digits of i.

  * In terms of these two definitions, the Boolean function f : _2^m _2 is bent if

    H_m f   = C [1, ‚Ä¶, 1]^T.

for some constant C.

sentence:
We define the non-diagonal-symmetry function œÑ_m on _2^2 m and _2^2 m
as follows.

For i in _2^2:

    œÑ_1(i) :=
    
    1    if¬†i = 10,¬†so that¬†Œ≥_1(i) = ¬±_2,

For i in _2^2 m - 2:

Let _m be the graph whose vertices are the n^2=4^m

of the Clifford algebra _m,m,
with each edge having one of two colours, -1 (red) and 1 (blue):


  * Matrices A_j and A_k are connected by a red edge if they have disjoint support and are anti-amicable,
i.e. A_j A_k^-1 is skew.

  * Matrices A_j and A_k are connected by a blue edge if they have disjoint support and are amicable,
i.e. A_j A_k^-1 is symmetric.

  * Otherwise there is no edge between A_j and A_k.

We call this graph the restricted amicability / anti-amicability graph
amicability / anti-amicability graph
of the Clifford algebra _m,m,
the restriction being the requirement that an edge only exists for pairs of matrices with disjoint support.

  at least one of the edges e_1 and e_2 is blue.

sentence:
A weakly increasing binary tree is
    
        
  * a binary tree that is not necessarily complete, i.e. , the nodes have arity 0, 1 (with two possibilities:
        either a left child or a right one) or 2;
        
  * the nodes are labeled according to the following constraints:
        
            
  * If a node has label k, then all integers from 1 to k-1 appear as
            labels in the tree. The set of labels is therefore a complete interval of integers 
            of the form {1,2,‚Ä¶,m} where m is the maximal label occurring in the tree. 
            
  * Along each branch, starting from the root, the sequence of labels is (strictly) increasing.

sentence: By the multiplication table of a group G=(G,‚àò) we mean the collection of triples (a,b,a‚àò b) for a,b‚àà G. The vertex set will be given by three disjoint copies of G called the row vertices , column vertices and label vertices . We shall refer to the triples as the edges or faces of the corresponding tripartite 3-uniform hypergraph. Typically, we will represent this as a labelled grid, with entry (a,b) given label a‚àò b. In the case that G=(G,+) is an abelian group, we will usually call the multiplication table an addition table .

sentence:
A simple flow grid of order n is a subgraph of C_n consisting of all the vertices of C_n for which four edges are incident to each internal vertex: either four edges

same direction and two vertical edges pointing in the same direction.

sentence:
Let d be a positive integer.
Build a sequence T(0), T(1), ‚Ä¶ of rooted random trees as follows.
The tree T(0) has just one vertex, the root.
For each 1‚â§ t‚â§ n, T(t) is obtained from T(t-1) as follows:
a leaf of T(t-1) is chosen uniformly at random
and gives birth to d new children.
The tree T(n) is called a random d-ary recursive tree on dn+1 vertices.

A pair {C_1,C_2} of disjoint k-cliques in a connected graph is an s-barrier if

A pair {C_1,C_2} of disjoint k-cliques in a connected graph is an s-barrier if
(i) the set of edges between C_1 and C_2 is a cut-set, i.e. deleting them disconnects the graph, and

sentence:
[Random k-Apollonian process]
Let k be a positive integer.
Build a sequence A(0), A(1), ‚Ä¶ of random graphs as follows.
The graph A(0) is just a clique on k vertices.
This k-clique is marked as active .
For each 1‚â§ t‚â§ n, A(t) is obtained from A(t-1) as follows:
an active k-clique of A(t-1) is chosen uniformly at random,
a new vertex is born and is joined to all vertices of the chosen k-clique.
The chosen k-clique is marked as non-active , and all the new k-cliques are marked as active in A(t).
The graph A(n) is called a random k-Apollonian network (k-RAN) on n+k vertices.

sentence:
Given two sequences of nonnegative integers a = (a_1, a_2, ‚Ä¶, a_n) and
b = (b_1, b_2, ‚Ä¶, b_m) having the same sum,  a majorizes b,  written a  b, if the

    ‚ãÆ


    a_1 + a_2 + ‚ãØ + a_n-1‚â• b_1 + b_2 + ‚ãØ + b_n-1.

If one weakens the sum requirement to the inequality ‚àë_i a_i
‚â•‚àë_i b_i, then a is said to weakly majorize b, written a ‚âΩ b.  
Majorization forms a partial ordering on integer sequences.

  * We say that B is grid-unimodal if it is grid-connected and B‚à© ({i}√ó [m-1]) and B‚à© ([n-1]√ó{j}) are connected (that is, intervals), for every i and j.

Finally, we define the W-random template¬†t_W(n) and the W-random colouring¬†c_W(n) by selecting the points X_1, X_2, ‚Ä¶,¬†X_n uniformly at random from [0,1], and then taking the resulting (induced) k-colouring template and random k-colouring respectively.

A two-terminal series-parallel graph (G;x,y) is defined recursively as follows:
	
		
  * Let V(K_2)= {0,1}.Then (K_2;0,1) is a two-terminal series-parallel graph.
		
  * (The parallel construction) Let (G;x,y) and (G';x',y') be two vertex disjoint two-terminal series-parallel graphs. Define G‚Äù to be the graph obtained from the   union of G and G' by identifying x and x' into a single vertex x‚Äù, and identifying y and y' into a single vertex y‚Äù. Then (G‚Äù;x‚Äù,y‚Äù) is a two-terminal series-parallel graph.
		
  * (The series construction) Let again (G;x,y) and (G';x',y') be two vertex  disjoint two-terminal series-parallel graphs. Define G‚Äù to be the graph obtained from the union of G and G' by identifying y and x' into a single vertex x‚Äù. Then (G‚Äù;x,y') is a two-terminal series-parallel graph.
	
	A graph is a series-parallel graph if there exist some two vertices x, y such that (G;x,y) is a two-terminal series-parallel graph.
